homeHero.Title: Konvikti
homeHero.subTitle: A home for theology students and other students in Kruununhaka and Ullanlinna
homeHead1.Title: A student residence in the heart of Helsinki.
homeHead1.Text: Konvikti has provided a home for theology students since 1917. Our mission is to offer a pleasant, affordable, and academically enriching place to live for the next hundred years of theology students—as well as for students interested in theology and Christianity.
homeHead1.Sub: Would you like to live in a historic setting right next to the university?
homeBrief2.Subtitle: In 1917, Herman Råbergh founded a support association for a home for poor and talented theology students, with the aim of supporting the studies of future generations of theologians. Our mission remains the same—we prioritize theology students and academic achievement in resident selections.
homeBrief.Subtitle: Konvikti in brief
homePunch1.Title: Founded in 1917
homePunch1.Text: In 1917, Herman Råbergh founded a support association for a home for poor and talented theology students, with the aim of supporting the studies of future generations of theologians. Our mission remains the same—we prioritize theology students and academic achievement in resident selections.
homePunch2.Title: A homelike environment...
homePunch2.Text: Konvikti is easy to arrive at and comfortable to live in. Compared to typical student dormitories, Konvikti offers both pleasant facilities and a warm, welcoming community.
homePunch3.Title: ...for theologians
homePunch3.Text: We prioritize theology students in resident selections. Beyond that, Konvikti residents don’t share any single background—people are interested in different areas of theology and come from different towns and congregations. Many have said that one of the great strengths of studying at Konvikti is this diversity.
homePunch4.Title: Easy living
homePunch4.Text: The student residence provides essentials such as cleaning supplies, well-equipped kitchens, and a washing machine. You only need furnishings for your own room—and even those can be available. Tidiness is maintained through weekly kitchen and apartment cleaning shifts.
homePunch5.Title: Over 100 years of student life—and counting
homePunch5.Text: Over the last hundred years, Konvikti has expanded to include the Pikku-Konvikti apartment in Ullanlinna, survived hits during the bombings of Helsinki, housed future archbishops and respected academics, and hosted countless sitsits and late-night scholarly conversations. The story continues through every Konvikti resident.
infoHero.Title: Apply to Konvikti
infoHero.subTitle: Use and help shape our technology
infoHead1.Title: Our student residences
infoHead1.Sub: Would you like to study in a beautiful historic setting just steps from the university? Explore Konvikti’s available resident places!
infoHead2.Title: Resident applications
infoHead2.Sub: New residents are selected annually through the general application period in June–August. We also hold additional application rounds as needed.
bigConvictusCard.title: Iso-Konvikti
smallConvictusCard.title: Pikku-Konvikti
infoBrief2.Subtitle: Applicants to Konvikti are scored. Those with the highest scores are selected as residents as places allow. Theology students are prioritized once a minimum score threshold is met.
infoBrief.Subtitle: Konvikti in brief
infoPunch1.Title: Academic performance
infoPunch1.Text: Konvikti’s goal is to be an academically enriching environment. Academic performance is scored based on your application.
infoPunch2.Title: Community involvement
infoPunch2.Text: As a communal living arrangement, we value a willingness to take part in shared events. Interest in community life is assessed from your motivation letter.
infoPunch3.Title: Interest in theology and Christianity
infoPunch3.Text: Konvikti is a Christian student residence. Our residents come from many backgrounds, but we are united by an interest in theology and/or Christianity and congregational life. The academic, professional, or spiritual interest you express in theology or Christianity is scored based on your motivation letter.
infoPunch4.Title: Am I a good fit to apply?
infoPunch4.Text: Are you starting—or about to start—higher education studies, or are you already pursuing a degree? In addition to location, are you interested in Konvikti’s community and your academic or professional growth? Then you’re in our target group—don’t hesitate to apply!
infoPunch5.Title: A community strengthened by diverse backgrounds
infoPunch5.Text: Many have said the best part of Konvikti has been meeting different future theologians and others interested in the subject. Unlike most Christian student residences in Helsinki, Konvikti has historically been broadly ecumenical—residents are not selected based on any particular church affiliation or ideological background. What unites us is community and a shared interest.
infoHead3.Title: Resident application announcements
infoLastInfo.title: Were you selected?
infoLastInfo.sub: The warden will notify applicants of selections on the date specified in the application announcement. A place is granted to a theology student for six years and to students in other fields for three years. After that, the place can be renewed year by year.

history1.title: Founding
history1.description: The Konvikti Student Residence Support Association was founded in 1917. The founders were bishops of the Evangelical Lutheran Church who wanted theology students to have a home and a safe place in Helsinki.

history2.title: The first Konvikti
history2.description: In 1920, the student residence—Konvikti—was established. The word comes from the Latin convictus, meaning communal life. The residence initially operated at several addresses.

history3.title: Move to Meritullinkatu
history3.description: In the 1930s, the residence moved into what is now Iso-Konvikti. The apartments were named Manala, Kiirastuli, Mirkkula, and Taivas.

history4.title: Juurinen Student Residence, or Pikku-Konvikti
history4.description: Emil and Mimmi Juurinen donated two apartments on Pieni Roobertinkatu through their will—this became the origin of Pikku-Konvikti.

history5.title: Jukola, 1999–2024
history5.description: A former temperance home located in the stairwell at Meritullinkatu 22 was transferred for Konvikti’s use. It was named Jukola after its seven, later eight, resident places.

history6.title: Letting go of Jukola and Mirkkula
history6.description: Due to rising costs, the association had to give up both the rented Jukola apartment and the Mirkkula shares. Financial restructuring has stabilized operations for decades to come.

history7.title: A new era
history7.description: At 109 years old, Konvikti looks to the future—how can we best serve the founders’ purpose, the homeland, and Finland’s Christian church?
